div.p: 1. III:45 Wednesday.

Mr Beale and Mr Bartlett called on me early this morning for Toasts and a Hymn for the celebration of the coming 4th instt. I gave them eleven toasts which I had just written, and desired them to select such of them as they should approve, and if they wanted more, obtain them from some other person— I furnished these with reluctance having no talent at toasting; and being sure of bitter criticism upon every Toast that I give— They asked me also for a Hymn, but I declined to perform that Service. I told them that in composing the Toasts I had excluded every sentiment approaching to party Spirit of any kind. They said this was their own desire; but the consequence is that the Toasts are all flat— Yet even these wretched Toasts, took up some of my time this morning— Having transcribed from loose sheets, to the last Volume of this Diary, the Journal of September and part of October 1833. I commenced this day upon the break between 10. January and 31. March of the same year I have formed the purpose of filling up that Volume of which there are now more than 200 blank pages—for the accomplishment of this I give myself one hundred days, which will bring me to the close of the Season, and leave me nothing to undertake that I can accomplish before my departure for Washington— And all this must be subject to the intervention of accidents—perhaps of ill health, or other circumstances unwelcome to think of, in advance— In my visits this day to my Garden, I sowed in Pot N. 11. a white one, with four crushed Downton Strawberries for the seed— The alleys of my garden have at length been cleared of their coat of grass and weeds, and my cherries are all gathered— About two thirds of them by Robins and Cat-birds— I planted a row of Cherry Stones in the bed next the Nursery fence—
From a seedling cherry of last year, towards the fence— Josiah Adams junr was here and repaired a breach in my cellar-stairs— He asked me for a copy of the Oration upon the life and character of La Fayette, which I gave him— I resumed and continued my Catalogue of Medals and Coins for Charles— About Sunset I walked to the sixth Mile-stone. The weather was so cool, that we had fire in the dining room all day.
2. IV. Thursday.

I had devoted the day to the labours which I have assumed and promised myself large progress in the redemption of arrears in my last volume, but made very little. Jason Houghton a tax collector of the town of Milton brought me a tax bill, County and Town, of 75 cents, upon my 3 Acres of Penny-ferry Salt-marsh— My Son Charles came out from Boston with his daughter and dined with us— I gave him the portion of Coins and medals of which I had made out the list, but I found that this work was far from being finished— Immediately after dinner Mr Thomas L. M’Kenney of Philadelphia came in, and was desirous of seeing the monument and Tombs of my father and mother in and under the Meeting House— I went with him, and after a search at five or six different houses found the key to the cellar, and there after another long search found the keys of the interior of the house, but not of the vault where my father and mother lie buried— We went into the Meeting House and Mr M’Kenney read the monumental inscription upon the marble tablet, at the right hand of the pulpit as you go to it— Mr M’Kenney asked me for a copy of this Inscription, written, as the monument itself was erected by me— But as I take it for granted he will have no recollection of his request to-morrow, I told him I would send him a copy of it if he desired it— He saw the monument of Josiah Quincy the Patriot and of his wife in the burying yard, which led us into that abode of my fathers and my Sons— We went all over the yard and he viewed the marble monument of the Quincys, and the Granite Tombstones, erected by my father over the remains of his forefathers—Henry Adams, who died in 1647. Joseph Adams Senior who died in 1694. Joseph Adams junior who died in 1737 and John Adams Senior, who died in 1760— The original grave stones of Henry and the two Joseph’s still remain— The first is a granite stone, in which was inlaid a small square marble tablet bearing the obituary inscription, but that is gone—and so it is from every other stone of the same kind in the yard. about 1680 they began to use the Slate Stones with the Inscriptions cut into them— They have proved more durable, and those of Joseph Adams Senior and Abigail Baxter are still in a state of good preservation at the spot where they were deposited— But the marble slab inlaid in the granite tomb-stone of Henry Adams, erected by my father in 1817. is already broken, and there are some other marks of decay in one of the other tombstones, which will need to be repaired— The Quincy monument is also somewhat dilapidated— The marble pedestal is cracked, and one of the corners of the entablature is
broken off. The Epitaph written by me in 1802 is scarcely legible— The frosts of winter contract the ground, which the excavations to receive the coffins make hollow. In time, the ground upon the surface caves in; and every Spring the melting of the frost heaves up the surface, and the burdens upon it— There are self-planted trees growing out of some of the graves, and these uproot the grave-stones— The vaults along the sides of the yard, are of modern invention—within the last twenty-five years, and they are without epitaphs, or inscription, except in some cases of the mere name— Coll. M’Kenney took some pencil-minutes from the tombstones— The key of the vault containing the remains of my father and mother were not to be found— It was about Sunset when Coll. M’Kenney left me to return over Milton-Hill to Boston— Charles was already gone—and so was my regular occupation—
3. IV. Friday.

The weather has again changed suddenly to high summer heat, and the drought commences— My seedling plants this Season up are withering, and those that have the protection of the weeds will be likely to fare the best— My special solicitude is for the maples the appearance and growth of which I now witness for the first time— The seed that I brought from Philadelphia has succeeded best and I only regret that I had not taken ten times the quantity, that from Washington comes up differently—with seed leaves, and looks drooping and sickly— My tall apple and peach seedlings, which had so fair a promise of growth last year are both diseased this Season; but I have no remedy for their diseases— The apple-tree is infested by swarms of small green lice, which cover the ends of the shoots, and change into a small black fly; and there are with them swarms of black ants continually running up and down the shoots— They arrest the growth of the shoots and curl up the leaves as they first put forth— The disease on the peach is a mildew— The green lice also attack occasionally the tips of the willow shoots— I observe that wherever a seedling plum comes up, there is a gathering of Ants and that the leaves are eaten away— Kirke is proceeding in the process of weeding my garden— My arrears of Diary were the occupation of the day—with the papering of coins for Charles. In the Evening, I had left my house to visit Mrs. De Wint at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, when I saw a Carriage coming up the lane from Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s, which stopp’d at my gate— I returned and found Mr Snelling, Mr Lowell Mason, and Mr Stone— Mr. Snelling presented me a Letter of Introduction from Edward Brooks at Boston— They came as a Committee from the Boston Academy of Music, an Association incorporated 22. March 1833. for the purpose of promoting Education in the science and practice of music— They have purchased the building which was the federal Street Theatre, and are fitting it up for a Hall, for the performance of Concerts and Oratorios— They propose to open it with a religious solemnity, and they apply to me to deliver an Address upon the occasion. I had some conversation with them upon the Nature and character of the Institution, which I think very laudable, and which may be highly useful. I told them that I believed there was not in the world a civilized Nation which neglected the Art, and Science of Music so much as the People of this Country. And it was the more
remarkable, as we were rather distinguished for the taste and talent of painting— I rejoiced therefore, that this Institution had been formed, and hoped that it would tend to the promotion of Harmony, not only of sound, but of sentiment and of temper among the People— I said I felt myself honoured by their application to me to deliver the Address upon the opening of their building, though I feared, from the nature of my engagements, and the numerous applications of the same kind which I had been under the necessity of declining it would not be in my power. They said they had hoped that the peculiar character of this undertaking might induce me to make an exception in this case, and requested me to take the proposal into consideration, and to give them an answer hereafter—to which I agreed. They left with me two annual reports of the Academy—for 1833 and 1834, and two printed collections of hymns, anthems and songs performed at juvenile Concerts given by the Academy. After they left me I went to Mrs T. B. Adams’s; but she and Mrs De Wint were both at Mr. Millers and I did not see them.
4. IV. Saturday.— Fifty-ninth Anniversary of Independence.

Mrs De Wint with her daughter Elizabeth, and Mrs. Angier called this morning. At ten O’Clock Mr Beale came and took me to Mr Whitney’s, where we found Mr Solomon Lincoln—General Whitney of Deerfield, Mr Alexander H. Everett, and Mr Whitcomb with my Son Charles afterwards came there, with some other Gentleman— There the procession consisting of the Citizens of the Town, preceded by their Committee of Arrangements, and escorted by one Quincy military company in a blue Uniform, and one Hingham company in scarlet came and took the Orator of the day and the clergymen of the town, whom we accompanied to the Meeting House. Mr Thomas Greenleaf presided.— The performances were 1. A voluntary by the brigade Band. 2. A song written for the occasion, by Mr Pierpont, excellent, and sung by Mr Coburn. 3. Chorus by the Choir 4. Prayer by Revd. Peter Whitney. 5 Anthem. 6. Declaration of Independence read by Revd. W. P Lunt 7. Hymn. 8. Oration by Solomon Lincoln of Hingham. 9. Ode—Air Pilgrim Fathers, written for Mr Coburn, and sung by him. 10. Anthem 11. Benediction by Revd. Mr Whitney— The whole occupied about two hours, and from the Meeting House the company proceeded to the dinner which was prepared under a tent upon the lot given by my father to the Town, and called the Hancock lot; because the House in which John Hancock was born, stood upon it.— Mr Lincoln’s Oration was a very good one, without any infection of party Spirit—giving due honour to the Patriots of the Revolution, and especially noticing those, who were natives or inhabitants of this Town— Pointing to the benefits which we have derived from our National Independence, and indicating the means by which they are to be preserved and perpetuated— Inviolable attachment to the Union
the Freedom of the Press, and the discipline of the Militia— He was about an hour in the delivery, and was very warmly applauded— I walked with the Procession to the entrance of the Lot, and then left them, came home and dined with my family— Charles dined with the company, but left the table early, and came to me— I gave him my papers on the Patronage Bill, which I had found this morning. Mr Everett, Mr. Whitney and Mr Whitcomb soon after came, and Charles returned with them to Boston— The morning was warm, but with a fresh breeze, and in the afternoon a succession of light showers besprinkled the ground— In the Evening I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where I found Mrs. De Wint, Mrs Angier and her husband. Elizabeth De Wint was at Mr Miller’s— Mrs De Wint is labouring with a severe rose or blossom cough; and declines coming to stay some days with us— She says she is asthmatic and homesick— My labours were this day suspended; and I only topped two seedling Peach trees in the Eastern close—14 inches tall.
5. IV. Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt, this morning, from Job 28.12. [“]But where shall wisdom be found? and where is the place of Understanding?” and 20. [“]Whence then cometh wisdom? and where is the place of Understanding?” and 32.8. “But there is a Spirit in man: and the inspiration of the Almighty giveth them understanding.” He considered the second text as the answer to the first, and the purpose of the discourse was to shew that the Spirit of God operates by direct agency upon the mind of man, as effectively as it does upon the material world— This approaches to the quaker doctrine; but must nevertheless be true— How the accountability of man is to be reconciled, with this superintending and inspiring power of the Almighty is a problem yet to be solved— Pope says that the Great first Cause, binding Nature fast in Fate left free the human will— But if the Will be free, how is it influenced by the inspiration of the Almighty.— If the Understanding comes by inspiration, how does it depend upon the Will of Man? If Wisdom comes from inspiration, whence comes Folly?— Mr Lunt did not enter into these discussions, nor into an examination of the doctrine of inspiration as taught by the Methodists, and high Presbyterian Calvinists; but asserted that the doctrine of divine influences upon the mind, was true in a certain sense. I took my two Granddaughters to meeting with me, for the morning service— Elizabeth C. Adams and Isaac Hull Adams, and Mary Harrod were there— Elizabeth and Mary Harrod from New-Orleans. Isaac Hull, from West Point— They arrived at 2 O’Clock this Morning— The afternoon Sermon was from Matthew 19.24 “And again I say unto you, It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.” The figure of speech, Mr Lunt said was a proverbial expression among the Jews, but he did not give his authority for the assertion— It has much more the air of an original expression of Jesus Christ, who never spoke but in Parables— The meaning here of the words, the kingdom of God is—the Christian Religion— There is great severity in the remark; but its application must be restricted to the circumstances under which it was made— The young man came anxiously to enquire what good thing he should do, that he might have eternal life— Jesus referred him to the Commandments and the observances of the Mosaic Law— This then according to Jesus was sufficient for his Salvation— But the young man had kept all these from his Youth up.— For all this there had been no promise made of eternal Life— This was brought to light by the Gospel, and for its enjoyment something more than the Law from Sinaï required— Jesus told him then if he would be perfect he must go, and
sell all that he had and give to the poor; and then come and follow him— The young man demurred—he went away sorrowing, for he had large possessions— This is all human nature— The gospel is the religion of the poor. Mr Lunt enumerated the temptations to which riches are liable, and which disqualify their owners for Christianity; but as the theme is somewhat invidious, he dispensed his rebukes with gentleness— I read the fourteenth Sermon of the sixth volume of Saurin— The last of the Volume— Upon the tranquility bred from perfect Charity— The text is from 1 John 4.18 [“]Perfect love casteth out fear”— So is it in the English Bible— In Saurin’s text it is perfect Charity banisheth fear— But the Charity of the New Testament is synonymous with brotherly love, and is the vital Spirit of Christianity. The preacher perplexes himself with the effort to reconcile the doctrine of his text with that of the fears which it is his habitual duty to rouse in the breasts of his heavers, for their own Salvation—and although the Discourse is elaborate, and written with great ability, it leaves an unsettled Sentiment upon the mind, between the banishment of fear by perfect charity, and the obligation of fear as a motive to repentance for sin— I read further some pages of Milman’s History of the Jews— There is an involuntary impression in reading this book that the Historian does not believe a word of the story that he tells— And such must be the impression from any attempt to assimilate the historical narrative of the Scriptures to the authenticated events of profane history— In the Bible, all is marvelous—all is miraculous— From the first chapter and verse of Genesis to the last of the Apocalypse, all is out of the order of Nature, and will not bear to be tested by the Laws of Nature as known to us.— There were light sprinklings of showers this afternoon; with the rumbling of distant thunder— They confined me to the house for the Evening.
6. III:30 Monday.

Elizabeth C. Adams and Isaac Hull Adams were here this morning immediately after breakfast— Elizabeth has been spending the winter at New-Orleans at her uncle Charles Harrod’s for the benefit of the climate; as she has been threatened with pulmonary complaints. Hull has a leave of absence from West Point where the annual examination of visitors has just been made, and where he says he made out better than he did last year.— Mr Lowell Mason, who with Mrs Mason was taking five young Ladies to school; perhaps at Hingham stopped here a few minutes, to explain to me that the object of the Boston Academy of Music was to make that Art a part of system of education— It was not a mere musical association, for musical pastime or amusement— It had occurred to him, that this had not been so explicitly stated to me, by himself and the Gentlemen who came with him last Friday as it should have been, and as they were conversing together on their return to Boston, it had been observed that the application to me would have been improper, if the Academy had been a mere musical Society— I told him I had understood them exactly as he now explained, and gave him my thanks, for a volume which I received yesterday; being the Manual of the Boston Academy of Music, for
instruction in vocal music, on the system of Pestalozzi—a small volume, composed by Mr Mason and published by the Academy.— I had no other interruption this day, but although I rose at half-past three of the morning, and was as assiduous in my labours as it is in my nature to be, it was an inefficient day— There was a heavy thunder shower from two to five in the afternoon— I visited repeatedly my Garden Nursery and Close, watching my seedling plants, but without discovering one new one any where— My young white mulberries however are for the first year, bearing fruit—two of them—the third though much older has never yet borne a berry— I give lessons of reading to my two Grand daughters, and learn what untiring perseverance and immovable Patience is necessary to practice the art of teaching— Accidents continually occur to occasion intermissions of the lessons, and after a single day’s intermission, the repugnance of the pupil to resume the study must be overcome— I wrote a short Letter this Evening to Mr Frye.
7. V:15. Tuesday.

Another inefficient day— Still more inefficient than yesterday— Mr Alpheus Spear came, and paid his rent for the quarter just expired: and I had some conversation with him concerning the renewal of his lease which expires the 31st. of next March— He wishes it renewed for five years, with Liberty on both sides to terminate the lease with one year’s notice— I told him I should raise the rent so as to include the taxes— Morning visits from Isaac P. Davis and Charles Codman—and afternoon visits from Mrs Baxter, her daughter and Son in Law— My Son Charles came out with his daughter, and dined with us. The third number of his appeal from the new to the Old Whigs was published this morning in the Boston Daily Advocate— He told me that at the festival at Worcester yesterday upon the opening of the railroad Alexander H. Everett was grossly insulted, the company refusing to hear him speak, on suspicion that he was the author of the Papers under the signature of a Whig Anti-mason. Governor Lincoln presided at the feast, and endeavoured to obtain a hearing for Mr Everett, but without success— I urged Charles to keep himself firm, and not to be discouraged— I received from the Secretary of the Navy, a Warrant of acting Midshipman, for my nephew John Quincy Adams 2d. and this Evening went to his mothers and informed her of the fact. She had returned this day from Medford, where she went last Evening with Mrs De Wint and her daughter Elizabeth— They are to go upon their return to New-York on Thursday— After the rain of yesterday, which refreshed my seedling plants, I discovered only one new comer, a Philadelphia maple, breaking through the ground of the box in the Eastern close next the road— There was one there up already— The Philadelphia Maples come up much alike— No seed—leaves— The plumelet pierces its way through the ground, rises about an inch, and opens two regular maple leaves, about a week after, the plumelet rising another inch opens two more maple leaves at right Angles with the first pair— In another week it rises and opens a third pair of leaves, again at right Angles with the second— Here are now those which I sowed on the first of June, and the first of which came up on the 22d Those that first came up are the most vigorous— I gathered five large Nursery Downton Strawberries, which I crushed and sowed in five places at suitable intervals on the ground under the Northern fence of the Eastern close— The day thus slipped away, and I wrote only a few lines besides the Journal of yesterday.

8. III:45. Wednesday. I had this day no interruption, and yet accomplished very little more than the two preceding days— The weather of the morning was sultry, and I spent three hours of it in my Garden, Nursery and Eastern close— About Noon, I found myself so feeble and so much overcome by weariness that I could neither read nor write. I threw myself on my bed, and slept till two— After dinner it was cooler and I partly redeemed the day— Continued my list of coins and medals— At dusk I went to Mrs T. B. Adams’s and gave the Cadet a Letter that I had received for him this morning— Elizabeth C. Adams and Mary Harrod were visiting at Mrs Baxter’s, with Isaac Hull, but they returned, and Miss Hannah Miller came in before I came home— John Glover and Joseph Crane came last Evening while I was out, and left a certificate of Noah Curtis, that the land covered by the Engine-house in Franklin-Street, so he calls the road on which my Quincy Meadow borders, is twelve feet six inches on the road and seventeen feet deep, including the foundation— See my Journal of 15 September last for the terms on which I agreed to give them a Lease of the Land for five or ten years— I met them as they were going from my house— This afternoon I continued my list of Medals and Coins for Charles.
9. III.30 Thursday

My garden, nursery and Eastern close Nursery, are now so fully stocked with seedling plants of fruit and forest trees of my own sowing that it absorbs hours of time merely to look at them. I sowed yesterday half a dozen ripening white mulberries in a broken earthen pot N. 14. to ascertain if the seed will vegetate— My Nursery is overburdened with young forest trees, which grow there with great rapidity— Especially the Horse Chesnut Elm, English white Oak, Red and Chesnut Oaks, Button wood, and Ash—to which I may add the Black walnut—of all which I have several trees growing— I finished for the second time since I came home, weeding my new Eastern close Nursery— The second shoot of my Chesnut and red Oaks, is now coming out, and a fourth pair of leaves forming on the plumelet of one of the Philadelphia Maples— I trimmed down an old Peach tree in the Garden, near the dwarf Apple tree, which bears this Season, very full— Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us, as did my Son Charles who came out from Boston alone. I gave him the remainder of my Collection of Coins and Medals—of which I have made out a list, in a confused state, and requiring future arrangement. The Revd. Mr Lothrop, now Minister of the Brattle Square Church in Boston, and MrEmerson, teacher of a female School or Academy in the City came after dinner to invite me to deliver an introductory Lecture or Address to the Institute of Instruction, for their course of Lectures to commence in the course of the next Month— I declined this invitation, as I have so many others, for which I have no time, and for which besides I do not feel myself well qualified— It seems to me that I have no faculty for writing or speaking upon anything that is not controversial. I had much conversation with Messrs Lothrop and Emerson,
upon various topics, Literary, political and religious, on all which I had much more than my share of the talking— Towards Evening I walked to Coll. Quincy’s; but found him and his family going out to a party at Mr Beale’s—Mrs Quincy the elder and her daughter Anna, were also there— On returning home I found an invitation from Mr Beale, to his party, and immediately went in—the Greenleafs, Whitneys, Lunt’s, Millers and Quincy’s were there; Dr Woodward and Isaac Hull Adams and his Sister Elizabeth C. Adams— Mrs Quincy the younger, Ann Beale and Hannah Miller, played on the Piano and sung Songs—in which the Cadet also joined— The party broke up between ten and eleven— I came home and went to bed unwell as I have been these three days without precisely knowing what my ailment is— It arrests the redemption of arrears both of my Journal and Correspondence—

10. IV. Friday Rainy morning, and a cold Northeasterly wind the whole day— The redemption of my arrears of Diary is arrested by the want of the Journal of the House of Representatives of the second Session of the 22d. Congress— This put me upon the Search among my old pamphlets, of which I have thousands—lumbering a multitude of Trunks Chests and boxes, and increasing in numbers almost every day— To assort them and select from them those that are worth binding, is a Herculean task, which I shrink from undertaking— In the attempt to collect together the loose sheets of the Journal that I wanted, a large portion of the day was wasted. In the process, I collected a considerable number of my own compositions, several of which are so intermixed with other voluminous matter that they are like two grains of wheat, in two bushels of chaff— The course of my occupations being thus interrupted, to avoid a total loss of time, I wrote four short Letters, one of which, to Mr Samuel Burch, Chief Clerk in the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives of the United States— I spent also three hours in my garden, Nursery and Eastern close; looking at my seedling trees; for I do little more, and learn nothing, from obtuseness in the faculty of observation and sluggishness in that of reflection— Kirk has weeded the alleys in the garden, and part of the garden itself— I this day made him head down a Peach tree about seven years old, apparently dead, but the main stem of which appears to be alive— For evening walk, I went to Mrs T. B. Adams’s; I gave Elizabeth two Letters which I had received for her this morning from New-Orleans— I found there a young Lieutenant Campbell, from Albany, a companion of Isaac Hull Adams— They were going to Mr Miller’s. John Marshall, Chief Justice of the United States died at Philadelphia last Monday the 6th instt. He was one of the most eminent men that this Country has ever produced— He has held this appointment thirty-five years— It was the last act of my father’s Administration, and one of the most important services, rendered by him to his Country— All Constitutional Governments are flexible things—and as the Supreme Judicial Court is the tribunal of last resort for the Construction of the Constitution and the Laws, the Office of Chief Justice of that Court is a station of the highest trust—of the deepest responsibility; and of influence far more extensive than that of the President of the United States— John Marshall was a federalist of the Washington School— The associate judges, from the time of his appointment have generally been taken from the democratic or Jeffersonian party—not one of them excepting Story has been a man of great ability. Several of them have been men of strong prejudices, warm passions, and contracted minds— One of them occasionally insane— Marshall, by the ascendancy of his genius
by the amenity of his deportment, and by the imperturbable command of his temper has given a permanent and systematic character to the decisions of the Court and settled many great constitutional questions favourably to the continuance of the Union— Marshall has cemented the Union, which the crafty and Quixotic Democracy of Jefferson had a perpetual tendency to dissolve— Jefferson hated and dreaded him— Marshall kept Jefferson much under the curb; some times, as perhaps in the case of Aaron Burr’s conspiracy too much so—but Marshall’s mind was far better regulated than that of Jefferson— It is much to be feared that a successor will be appointed of a very different character— The President of the United States now in Office has already appointed three judges of the Supreme Court; with the next appointment he will have constituted the Chief Justice, and a majority of the Court— He has not yet made one good appointment— His Chief Justice will be no better than the rest— The death of Judge Marshall has occurred under Circumstances of deep melancholy— His disease was the stone—he had been saved and relieved about three years, by the operation of the lithotomy performed with consummate skill by Doctor Physick— He had now been brought, a few days before his death to Philadelphia, for a further and last resource to save him— His eldest Son, a man of more than forty years of age, having a wife and family of six children, was at Baltimore, on his way to Philadelphia, to sooth with filial affection and tenderness the last moments of his father’s life, when by the falling of the timber of a house in a Tornado, upon his head he was mortally wounded, and died after being trepanned three or four days before his father. Oh! how much suffering is in the best and happiest condition of human existence.
11. IV:15. Saturday— My Birth day—68 years completed.

A man by the name of Barnard Sargent from Milton, came about a section of Military bounty land, granted by a deed from President Monroe in 1820. to the heirs of his grandfather, whose name he bears, and who was a soldier in the last War— The heirs besides himself are six from all of whom he has Quit claim deeds— The land has been sold for twelve dollars for the payment of taxes, though he says he did send to some one the money to pay the taxes— The purchaser of the Land however, together with a person named Joseph Burns, has proposed to pay him fifty dollars for a Deed in which all the right of the grantees should be conveyed to them— He shewed me two Letters from Burns, one written last Winter, proposing to pay the money through David Spangler, their Representative in Congress to me the Representative of Sargent, and that the Deed should be transmitted, through me to Mr Spangler for them— But in a subsequent Letter, he says they have paid the money to Governor Cass, the Secretary of War, and requests that the Deeds may be
transmitted to him— Mr Sargent came to ask for my advice.— He said he was willing to give for the fifty dollars a Quit-claim Deed for all the heirs, but not a general Warranty. I told him if he would bring me such a Quit claim Deed, duly expected, I would send it to a person at Washington who would deliver it to Governor Cass, and receive from him the Money, which I would then have paid to Sargent— He said he would have the Deed made out, and would bring it to me— Isaac Hull Adams and Lieutenant Campbell were here, and took the two children to Mrs T. B. Adams’s where they dined and passed the day. At one O’Clock we had a Meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School Fund— All the members present— It was three years since the last meeting— The principal business of this meeting was the preparation of an Indenture of lease for one hundred years of a house lot, upon the eight-acre Hancock lot given by my father to the town of Quincy— The Deed is of about half an Acre, to a widow, named Betsey Thayer, but Captain Underwood is building a House upon it— The Indentures were drawn, by Coll. Josiah Quincy junr.— There was some discussion upon their purport, and two amendments proposed and adopted— Reports were made by a Committee of the board, consisting of Mr Greenleaf and Mr Beale, upon several subjects referred to them at the last Meeting— The same Committee were continued for similar Services— The Indentures as amended are to be executed by the Supervisors together with the Selectmen of Quincy, and the Lessee, at a future day— The Committee were also authorised to lease verbally a small strip of Land at the Babel Pasture, and also to lease the Quarry upon reasonable terms. A vote passed also that the Indenture of Lease when executed should be recorded upon the Corporation Book— About three O’Clock the meeting was dissolved, and the members remained and dined with me—together with Mr Whitney and Mr Lunt, Daniel and E. Price Greenleaf, Doctor Woodward, and Alexander H. Everett, who came out with my Son Charles from Boston— They returned in the Evening. Mrs Quincy and her daughter Susan paid an afternoon visit to my wife— My daughter Mary gave me a light, neat umbrella-cane as a birth-day present—
12. IV.15. Sunday— Sun rose 4:33.

Heard Mr Alexander Young junr. Minister of the New South Church, Summer-Street. Boston— His morning text was from Proverbs 20.27. “The Spirit of Man is the candle of the Lord.” and that of the afternoon from Luke 12:6. “Are not five Sparrows sold for two farthings, and not one of them is forgotten before God.” The morning discourse was an argument against the prevailing infidelity of the age, materialism, and earnestly contended for the separate existence of the body and Soul— This distinction is clearly marked both in the old and the New Testament—most especially in the Book of Ecclesiastes Chapter 12. verse 7. where it is said that after death the dust shall return to earth as it was: and the spirit shall return to God who gave it— But Job says that in the flesh he shall see God, and Saint Paul expressly affirms the resurrection of the Body—a spiritual body—incorruptible, and therefore no longer subject to the Laws of matter— Mr Young’s afternoon Sermon, was an exhortation against cruelty to inferior animals—an Article of Christian morality perhaps not sufficiently attended to, by many otherwise good men— Cruelty to the brute creation, is seldom instigated by Malice or anger, but is the result of wantonness or insensibility— It does not belong to the natural disposition of man, but is an instinct of depraved nature.
Mr Young had many historical allusions in his Sermons, indicating his familiarity with by-paths of Literature, not much travelled by his clerical associates of the present age— He adverted particularly to the distressing circumstances under which Boethius wrote his book on the Consolation of Philosophy.— He cited also a long passage from Milton on his blindness; and referred to the distressed state of mind of Newton, towards the close of his life— I read the first Sermon of the seventh Volume of Saurin, upon Godly Sorrow a subject connected with a particular incident in the Church of Corinth for which they were severely reproved by Saint Paul— There is a mixture of philosophical speculation in many of the Sermons of Saurin, which gives to his discourses an elaborate character, and sometimes chills the ardour of his appeals to the sensibility of his hearers— I read also part of a Book of Milman’s History of the Jews, a Summary of the Law, delivered from Sinaï, or as Milman himself calls it, the Legislature of Moses in the Desert— This part of the work is altogether unsatisfactory— A philosophical analysis of this Hebrew Legislation, has not yet fallen in my way— It is probably in this Law, that is to be found the principle of that unexampled and permanent influence of the Jewish Nation over the fortunes and opinions and institutions of the rest of mankind— But in what it consists Mr Milman has not undertaken to shew— The foundation of it all, seems to be in the unity and omnipotence of God, first imagined or discovered by Abraham, and the two promises of God to him; first, the possession of the Land of Canaan to his descendants, and secondly that in him, all the families of the Earth should be blessed. My nephew the Cadet, Isaac Hull Adams and his companion Lieutenant Campbell dined with us, and I spend the Evening at Mr Edward Millers— His daughter performed on the Piano, and sung, accompanied by the two young men and Mr Miller, some of the Psalms, and other Church Music— Coll. Quincy, Mrs Miller, and Anna Quincy, Mr Beale and his daughter, Mrs Charles Miller, Mrs Ripley and Doctor Woodward, Mrs T. B. Adams, Elizabeth C. Adams, and Mary Harrod were there— The Lieutenant and the Cadet are to depart to-morrow for Albany and West-Point—
13. IV:15. Monday

Bent is the Baker from Milton, who brought me his Bill— Elizabeth C. Adams and Mary Harrod were here early this Evening— There was a distant thunder Shower ranging from West and North to East, of which only a corner came to us.— This is the usual range of our thunder clouds. Before Sunrise the sky was covered with Clouds— Wind at South west— In three hours after Sun rise, the Clouds were all swept away and the Sky was clear; with the heat of the Sun so intense, that it drove me from my garden and Nursery to shelter in the House—but I planted a cross row of white mulberries, and one of mazzard cherry-stones, at the North-eastern corner of my Seminary, under the Northern fence of the Eastern close— It was a withering day to my seedlings of this Season— Kirke and Wilson rectified my western fence, bordering on my neighbour Beale— I resumed the task of redeeming arrears in my Journal of February 1833. without making due progress; but I consulted Marshall’s book or gardening, and Evelyn’s Silva and
Terra,—for directions about planting. The Oaks and Pignuts that I headed down in the Summer-house cellar, are putting out shoots; as the Peach and Pear trees have done in the patch fronting my chamber window— The clouds were gathering all day, and occasionally intercepting the Sun; which saved many of my plants from perishing— As the Sun went down, the clouds from the South and Southwest, settled in the West and North, and soon after Sunset the Lightning began to flash; and continued till our bed time— I went out and viewed it for half an hour. E. Price Greenleaf stopped returning from his uncle Daniel’s who had lost his voice in making hay—from the heat of the Sun— All the neighbourhood is hay-making.
14. IV. Tuesday—

A Summer day of furnace heat— Thermometers in open air above 90. It disqualified me for writing and made me idle— But my chief concern in these days of blazing Sun, is for my seedling Plants of the present year— One such day will kill them by hundreds, if unshaded— I shingled several of those in my seminary, and saw the necessity of protecting all that I wish to save— This afternoon, Mr Solomon Lincoln called upon me with Mr Charles Lane of Hingham, who has invented an improved Fire-grate for burning coal, or wood— He left his papers with me; being a Petition for a Patent, with Specification and authentication by Oath before Mr Lincoln, who shewed me his Commission as a Justice of Peace, and a receipt in duplicates of L. W. Bridge a Teller of the Commonwealth Bank, for 30 dollars, to the Treasury of the United States— Mr Lane requested me to transmit these Papers to the Secretary of State, and expressed his anxiety to receive his Patent as soon as possible— I promised to forward his Papers immediately— E. Price Greenleaf came and invited me to go and view his Plantation Nursery— We were accompanied by his father— His seedling fruit-trees make as yet, but little Show— But the Tulip-trees and Button-woods grow rapidly. While I was out Mr Snelling, with Mr Lawrence, came from Boston, for my answer to the invitation to deliver an Address upon the opening of the Boston Academy of Music, at their new building; once the Federal Street Theatre— I have concluded to decline the delivery of this Address— It is one of the modes of public speaking which have lately become fashionable; and for which men in public life, are very freely taxed— The origin of most, if not all of them is in the Phi Beta Kappa Orations. But they are multiplied almost as the Stars of Heaven— And almost without exception they are forgotten, the day after they are delivered. This would certainly be the fate of mine, and I should lose instead of gaining reputation, by complying with the numerous invitations which I receive to deliver such Addresses, Orations, Discourses and Lectures.— They are in truth all Sermons—but if one of these Institutions should invite an Orator to deliver a Sermon, it would go nigh to break up the fashion—
15. IV. Wednesday.

Elizabeth C. Adams, and Mary Harrod this morning took my Grand daughter Mary-Louisa with them to Medford where they go to spend some days with Mrs Angier— They went hence in the Stage to Boston and thence in another Stage to Medford— My Son Charles came out from Boston, with his daughter, who is to remain some days here— His wife with her two other
children are at Medford on a visit to her father— This was to me another day of comparative idleness— The morning was beclouded but sultry.— I visited my seedling plants, and finding those of the present year, withering with the heat of the Sun, am endeavouring to save some of them with old shingle guards— Kirk began weeding the alleys of my Nursery. The Nectarines are falling from the tree at the North end of the Nursery; but the Oaks, and Hickories which I headed down, as well as those mowed by Carr’s Scythe, indiscriminately with the weeds, are all thriving with new Shoots— The Maple that first came up in my Seminary on the 25th. of June, this day opens its fifth pair of leaves— Those in the Pots come forward not so fast— Those from the Washington seeds, which threw out their seed leaves are perishing— A dark coloured water-snake five feet long was found yesterday among our rasberry vines and killed— We had in the afternoon and evening between 4. O’Clock and ten at Night three thunder showers, with a heavy fall of rain— I wrote to the Secretary of State, Forsyth, and enclosed the Petition and papers for a Patent which he had left with me yesterday—and I wrote an answer to Messrs. Snelling, Lowell Mason and Stone, declining to deliver the Address, at the opening of the building for the Boston Academy of Music— The redemption of the arrears of my Diary languishes.
16. IV. Thursday.

Heavy rain, in the Night and when I rose this morning— It poured in streams with frequent flashes of Lightening without thunder—after which succeeded a gale with beating rain till about 8 O’Clock when it subsided— There were two or three light showers in the course of the day; and the Sun set clear. There was a meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University, at the Council chamber in Boston, which it was my intention to attend, but the weather diverted me from this purpose. My Son Charles however, returned to Boston, leaving his daughter Louisa Catherine here. I had no aptitude for labour, and wasted great part of the day in my Garden Nursery and Seminary, doing nothing— Not even weeding— But I planted in a cracked, white Earthen Pot. 10. Keen Seedling Strawberries. 6. white mulberries and 5. mazzard cherry-stones— I had last year remarked the difference of the colour of the Earth in the two kinds of my earthen ware flower Pots— One set white and glazed— The other merely baked earth of the colour of bricks— The white retained longer the moisture of the Earth with which they were filled— I have now made the experiment, by pouring a quart of water in two of the stands of each kind one pair in a closet of my chamber—the other within the porch below— In both instances, the water in the plain baked earth was absorbed or evaporated in four or five days, but not in the white-glazed ones— I must repeat this experiment with more care and attention— I shingle guarded several of my seedlings in the Seminary, and topped several of my growing Peach trees— Towards Evening I walked to the sixth Mile Stone; and on my return found Mr Beale, and his daughter here on an Evening visit— My progress on the arrears of my journal was rather more than for some days past, but still too little.
17. IV. Friday.

The weather has so much influence upon my condition and occupations that it forms almost an essential part of my Journal— The day was fine—the sky was clear, with a cool South easterly breeze but the heat of the Sun warns me to guard my seedling trees of the present year from the fierceness of his beams— I shelter several of them in the seminary every day— Those in the garden are perhaps sufficiently sheltered, by the old trees.— Wilson opened for me this afternoon a border along the Eastern end of my house where there were already a few flowers— I planted two short cross-rows of mazzard cherry-stones, at the eastern end of my Seminary; and repeated my experiment of exposing a bottle of water in a white glazed flower pot stand; and one in another brick-coloured stand; to ascertain the difference of the time in which the water will evaporate from them—both being exposed to the Sun— My labour was confined to the arrears of my journal, in which I made some progress— The fourth number of Charles’s appeal from the new to the old whigs was this day published in the Boston Advocate. Mr Brooks of Hingham was here this afternoon— He went to Europe last year, and on his return was a fellow-passenger with Miss Martineau. Mrs. T. B. Adams and Louisa C Smith were here also, and after tea I walked with them home.

18. IV. Saturday.— Sun rose 4:38. Yesterday and this morning I saw Venus and Jupiter in conjunction as morning Stars just one sign of the Zodiac in precedence of the Sun. By perseverance in writing without visiting my garden before breakfast I am enabled to redeem a portion of arrears in the last volume of my journal; but if I step outside of the House, the day or a large portion of it is lost. At this Season, the heat of the Sun makes it almost impossible for me to labour at the cultivation of my plants, and I do little more than saunter, over my grounds in search of something to observe, and from obtuseness of intellect discovering nothing from which I can draw a profitable inference— I procured this day four new Earthenware Pots, and in one of them planted six fresh mazzard cherry stones—and in its stand, I deposited 28 stones of the same kind, which have been six days soaking in Water— I discovered one pignut just up in the garden near the Jargonel grafted pear tree—one in the Summer house cellar, putting out a new shoot from a stem of the last year, so slender, that it had till this day escaped my notice, and after an interval of nearly a fortnight two Oaks newly up in the seminary— I see the effect of the Sun upon the vegetation of the seedling plants— It scorches the leaves, arrests the progress of the plumelet, and suspends the active principle of vegetation— The leaf turns yellow, curls up, becomes speckled with rusty looking spots, and the plant dies— Yet they must have the light of the Sun, for they perish alike without it— Of four rows of Apple-seeds and Pear cores which in the autumn of 1833 I planted under the young elms at the Northern end of my Nursery, scarce half a dozen puny apple and pear trees, not one of them six inches high remains. I therefore continue shingle guarding my fresh seedlings in the Seminary, and especially see the necessity of protecting the young maples— The seed leaves of those from Washington have already mostly withered away.— I find in the newspaper called We the People, published at Bridgewater, a reply of the Whig Anti-mason, to some remarks which had appeared in that paper censuring the Political Speculations of the Whig Anti-mason, in the Boston Daily Advocate— And in the same number of We the People, the first Appeal from the new to the Old Whigs is also republished— I wrote to my nephew J. Q. Adams 2d. to enclose
his appointment as an acting Midshipman in the United States Navy, and the other papers for him received from the Navy Department.

19. III.45. Sunday— Heard Mr Cunningham of Dorchester, in the morning, from Luke 15.21. “And the son said unto him, Father, I have sinned against Heaven, and in thy sight, and am no more worthy to be called thy Son.”— The parable of the prodigal Son. There seems to be some danger that the true moral lesson to be learnt from this story should be mistaken— In order to draw Sinners to repentance, Jesus associated and conversed with them— This became a subject of censure and reproach against him, by the Pharisees and scribes; and it was in justification of himself that he spoke this parable— He had said that he came not to call the righteous but Sinners to repentance— That he came to save that which was lost. The purpose of this parable was therefore to bring out in the strongest relief the motives and inducements to repentance— The repenting Sinner, is thus made the most interesting personage of the story— There is something like moroseness in the offence taken by the blameless brother, at the affectionate kindness with which the returning truant is received by the father; and the declaration that there shall be more joy in Heaven over one sinner that repenteth than over ninety-nine just persons who need no repentance, may be perverted into a recommendation to sin, for the sake of after repentance. The object of this discourse was to correct such erroneous inferences, and to shew the superiority of condition, and the purer blessedness of the just person even over the enjoyments of the forgiven penitent— Mr Cunningham’s afternoon Sermon was from 2. Peter 3.1. [“]This second Epistle, beloved, I now write unto you; in both which I stir up your pure minds by way of remembrance: 2. That ye may be mindful of the words which were spoken before, by the holy prophets, and of the commandment of us the apostles of the Lord and Saviour.” The discourse was an argument to shew the obligation of Christians to make themselves more intimately and perfectly acquainted with their religion and its author— There is something peculiar in the Style of composition, and in the manner of delivery of Mr Cunningham, not pleasing, though not offensive— His prayers are too much studied— I took my two grand-daughters Fanny, and Louisa, to meeting with me this morning— I read the second Sermon of the seventh Volume of Saurin, upon the Grandeur of the Counsels of God, and the abundance of his means—the text is from Jeremiah 32.19.— And the preacher remarks upon the extreme difficulties with which the Minsters of the word of God have to contend when they are obliged to meddle with Politics— Such he says was the case with the prophet Jeremiah— This is a curious point of view from which that Book, and indeed all the prophesies of the old Testament might be considered— I read also the fifth Book of Milman’s History of the Jews—The Conquest of Canaan— He remarks upon the extreme uncertainty of the numbers, as they are noted in the old Testament; and a note at the beginning of the fourth Book page 119. leads the reader to the conclusion that the author has no faith in the position that the emigrant Israelites at the Exodus from Egypt numbered 600,000 fighting men— He wishes to retrench a cypher, or at least to take the 600,000 as the amount of the whole People— Even these are more numerous, than can be well accounted for to inhabit and find subsistence upon a territory less than fifty miles wide, and not more than 120 Miles long— It may be well to consult Hume’s Essay upon the populousness of antient Nations.
20. IV. Monday.

Warwick Palfray brought me this morning a bill for six years subscription to the Essex Register, a Salem Newspaper, which has been thus running on year after year, till the amount of the Bill is considerable— There are numbers of Newspapers sent to me thus, some of which I never ordered or subscribed for, and always finally followed by a Bill— There was in this case a half-year still left due; for the bill to run on, but I paid for that also and entered upon the receipt that the paper should be stopped. I desired Mr Palfray to say to his Son the Editor of the Paper that it was not from any dissatisfaction with it, but because I was obliged to reduce the number of Papers that I take. There has been a very extraordinary judicial decision in the State of New-York, that if the publisher of a newspaper sends it to a person without his orders or subscription and the receiver does not send it back, the publisher shall recover against him the price of the Paper, as if he had regularly subscribed for it— And upon the strength of this decision many publishers of newspapers send them without order or subscription to persons who may not be informed of this legal obligation, or will not take the trouble to send them back, and afterwards sue for the subscription— Mr Palfray’s visit was soon succeeded by Mr Michael Burns, a strolling retailer of New Books, who laid me under another contribution of ten dollars for a comprehensive Geographical, Historical, and Commercial Atlas, a Quarto volume of indifferent maps and petty Statistics compiled by T. G. Bradford, a Son of Alden Bradford— He brought me a note from the publishers of the Book soliciting my Patronage; this is the usual way of pedlaring off unsaleable Books— So as Dr Johnson said that the Booksellers were the modern Mecaenas’s of Literature in old England, the Pedlars may be called the Maecaenas’s of the United States of America. My Son Charles came out to dine and pass the night with us— In my visits to my garden, Nursery and Seminary, I found one more Philadelphia Maple up, in Pot N. 3. one in the box next the road, and one in Pot N. 6. planted on the 20th. of June.— I found also a bean coming up, which I threw in with the cross row of white mulberries, at the North-eastern end of my Seminary.
21. IV. Tuesday— Boston— Fishing party— Cohasset Rocks— Return to Quincy

Mr Edward Cruft had sent me an invitation from the President and Directors of the Atlas Insurance company in Boston, to go this day upon a fishing excursion below the Boston Light-House, and although there was a shower of rain this morning and the aspect of the weather was unpromising, I went into Boston with Wilson, in a Horse and Chaise of Gillets— At 8 O’Clock I reached Mr Cruft’s house, and thence walked with him to the Place of rendez-vous, Commercial wharf— We found the company already there, in a very neat small pleasure boat, belonging to Mr Cushing, called the Sylph— The company consisted of Samuel Adams Welles, President of the Atlas Insurance Company, Edward Cruft, Richard Devens,Harris, Joseph W. Lewis, Phineas Sprague, and Rezin D. Shepherd Directors of the Company, a Mr Cayler, Edward Everett, Peleg Sprague, Dr Wainwright and Mr James Walker a Minister of Charlestown— Just at nine O’Clock we left the wharf and in two hours we were beyond the Light-house rock and Point Alderton. After trying unsuccessfully two places for fishing grounds we found one near Cohasset rocks where the fish were in abundance, and in the course of two hours we caught about fifty Cod and Haddock, of which my own captures were three fine Cod— Soon after two O’Clock
there was a threatening appearance of an approaching squall, and it was thought prudent to leave the fishing ground, and return into the harbour, to be under the protection of the shore— The squall proved however merely a light shower of rain, succeeded by a fresh and pleasant breeze, and a clear sky— We dined upon Chowder and fried fish, after two luncheons of Cold roast, and salt Beef, Ham and Tongue, with Madeira, Sherry, Champagne, and Haut-Brion wines and Lemonade made by Mr Shepherd consisting of a Gallon of Water, a Bottle of Jamaica Rum, a bottle of Cognac Brandy, a Bottle of Champagne wine, a pint of lemon juice and a pound of loaf-sugar.— We came to anchor between 4 and 5. O’Clock, off Rainsford or Hospital Island the place of Quarantine— Several of us went on shore and visited Dr Smith now the Physician of the Island—the place so long occupied by Doctor T. Welsh. It was I believe thirty years, of not more since I was last upon the Island; but when I resided in Boston, after my return from Prussia, I went more than once, with the Selectmen of Boston, upon their annual dining party there. The appearance of the Island is now so different from what it was then, that I should scarcely have known it for the same. There is a new and neat hospital, built within the last five years—but there is now not a single vessel under Quarantine, nor a single Patient at the Hospital— Mr John Minot, the keeper of the Hospital together with Dr Jerome V. C. Smith, received and greeted us as visitors— Mr Minot told me that he had lost his place in the Custom-house for his zeal to promote my election as President of the United-States— After a short view of the Island, we returned on board of the Sylph, and reached our point of departure at Commercial wharf, about seven O’Clock. Wilson whom I had ordered to be there at that hour was waiting for me, with the Horse and Chaise— I parted from my companions, went to Charles’s House, and sent him the key of his Office, which he had lent me, and which I had forgotten to leave with Wilson for him— Charles had returned to Boston this morning, after I had left him this morning at Quincy— I came round by Mr Cruft’s house, took my fishing lines and umbrella which I had left there this morning, and in a short hour came home to Quincy— The day was pleasantly passed; though with a continual memento mori, in being reminded of the Multitudes of men of former generations with whom I have made similar excursions, or sailed up and down this harbour since the 10th. of February 1778 when I embarked on board the Boston Frigate in Nantasket roads, from the Beach at Mount Wollaston— My grand-child Mary-Louisa, returned this Evening with Elizabeth C. Adams, and Mary Harrod, from their visit at Mr John Angier’s in Medford— The fifth number of the Appeal from the new to the Old Whigs was this day published in the Boston Advocate, and in the Centinel.
22. IV: Wednesday

Father Francisco Lagons as he tells his own story, is a native of Catalonia in Spain, and was a Priest in that part of the Mexican dominion called California, situated on the Western side of the American Continent, and bordering on the pacific Ocean. He says that he was forced away from that Country by the decree of expulsion issued by the Government against all native Spaniards, and that he is in search of means to find his way home to Spain— He strolls about the Country as a mendicant, with certificates from the Spanish, and sundry other European Consuls at Boston, and Clergymen of town and Country hereabouts,
recommending him to the charity of the compassionate— I resumed my occupations, heard my Grand daughter Mary-Louisa read twice, had my back-cellar Staircase propped up, wrote something to bring up the arrears of my journal in March 1833, and visited my plantations in Seminary, Nursery and Garden.— I measured the Shagbark Walnut-tree near the Summer-house cellar, of which I planted the nut 7. Octr. 1804. It came up in the Spring of 1805. and is of course now thirty years old— A foot above the ground it measures 37. inches in circumference—3 1/2 feet above the ground 53 inches—four feet above the ground it parts in to two stems, and branches out. It is about thirty feet high, and a thrifty flourishing tree— It may be standing there a century from this day. It has hitherto borne little fruit, but for the last ten years a few nuts, all on the South-eastern side every year— There are four or five seedling trees in the Nursery from nuts of this tree which I planted in October 1830.— I filled a new Pot N. 19. with fresh Earth, and put into it, mazzard cherry stones, Strawberries and white mulberries— Elizabeth C. Adams and Mary Harrod took tea here— I went home with them, and found E. Price Greenleaf at Mrs. T. B. Adams’s— Walked home with him— He had called last Evening when I was absent, and promised to come and bud some cherry trees for me tomorrow. I found Mr John Glover at my house. He came for the lease of the ground upon which the fire Engine stands, but it was not ready— He also paid me 10 dollars for Noah Curtis for the rent of the Goose Pasture.
23. IV. Thursday.

The day was clear, and a bright Sun shone unclouded from morn to eve. The temperature of the atmosphere was mild and calm, with occasional light breezes— My principal concern was to shelter my seedlings in the Seminary, where my Philadelphia maple at the corner next the gate, first opens its sixth pair of leaves— It is just one Month since its first appearance, and fifty three days since the sowing of the seed— None of the others have grown so rapidly, and those from the Washington trees, give little promise of life— I gathered a quart of ripe thimbleberries, from the wine in my Nursery, and broke up a Nest of black caterpillars upon the willow in the Summer house cellar, and one of mouse coloured downy-haired Caterpillars upon my old Shagbark tree; also a tip stem covered with green lice, on the willow— I found also the first slug-worm, on the young cherry tree in the Nursery. Mr Price Greenleaf came this afternoon, and budded for me fourteen cherry-trees—eleven in the patch opposite the old shagbark tree—and three in the honey locust patch—with black-hearts, red hearts, Downer-red and white, and white hearts. Two buds in each tree— I had one seedling in the middle garden box; which he thinks is a Tupelo. I had been sometime conjecturing what it was— I heard my two Grand-daughters read, and continued to retrieve arrears of Journal in March 1833. The Evening sky was uncommonly clear, and I contemplated the Starry Heavens—
24. III.45 Friday— Jupiter and Venus widening apart Sun rose 4:43.

Wilson went to Boston this morning with an order from my Son Charles upon Forbes the livery-stable keeper, for a pair of horses, which Charles at the recommendation of Forbes had purchased for me, and paid for, 500 dollars— It turned out that one of the horses is unsound, and they were sent back to Forbes, but the seller refuses to take them back, and Forbes flinches from or denies his guaranty— The case is referred to an arbitration, and as the precise disease of the horse is not ascertained they were sent for to be tried again.
A man by the name of John Edson, of Bridgewater brought me a Subscription paper, for building an Episcopal church in that town, with a very earnest recommendation of this pious enterprize, signed by Bishop Griswold— It seems the Episcopalians of Bridgwater want a larger Church than they now have, and are willing that their neighbours should pay for their religious edification— They have accordingly formed a joint stock company of forty shares, one hundred dollars to a share; and each share holder is to have a pew— This paper Mr Edson presented to me, to sign, his own name standing at the head of it, for two shares— I take it for granted he is the contractor to erect or furnish the materials for the building— I told him that not being an Episcopalian, and not residing in Bridgewater, I had no occasion for a pew there; upon which he presented me another subscription paper for a donation. There was one name upon this, of an Episcopal clergyman at Newtown, for 25 dollars. I put down my name for ten, which I paid to Mr Edson, and he took leave— My Son Charles from Boston came to dine and spend the Night here— It was the second of a succession of midsummer days with a blazing Sun, which disqualified me alike for the garden and the writing-chamber, especially from dinner time, after which my debility was excessive. There is a paper in the Boston daily Advocate of this morning under the signature of A friend of Mr Adams, written by Alexander H. Everett, and to which, what will be the sequel?
25. IV. Saturday— Sun rose in haze 4:44.— New Moon.

My Son Charles returned this morning to Boston— I received a Letter from George Sullivan of New-York, with an application from the Managers of the American Institute of that City to me, to deliver the Address at their annual Fair, next October Sullivan’s Letter mentioned that Dr Matthews the Chancellor of the new University at New-York, was coming to Boston, and would visit me: he came accordingly this morning with his daughter and two other young Ladies— He said there had been much correspondence upon the subject of instituting a National Literary and Scientific Academy at New-York; a project upon which I had attended a Literary convention there in October 1831. That he should wish to exhibit this correspondence to me, as there were many distinguished Gentlemen, particularly of the South, who were desirous of carrying this purpose into effect— I did not decline the inspection of the Correspondence, but he alluded to the reluctance and aversion which I had found in Philadelphia to the promotion of this Scheme, four years ago, and of which I had informed him— It satisfied me, that if an Institution, like that projected by Dr Matthews was ever to be accomplished it must be in an after age, and when the Sciences shall be more ardently cultivated than they are in this Country at the present time— I did not say to Dr. Matthews, but I felt, that my ignorance of all the Sciences of calculation and of Speculation, made me unfit to be at the Head of such an Institution, and that my age unfits me for any undertaking the usefulness of which depends upon the efficient ardour, constant exertion and undiscourageable perseverance with which it is pursued. I am drawing close upon the verge of seventy— I have done nothing, I have no ability to do any thing that will live in the Memory of mankind— My life has been spent in vain and idle aspirations, and in ceaseless
rejected prayers, that something should be the result of my existence beneficial to my own Species— It is time for me to abandon all such imaginations, and to close my accounts with this world— The National Academy of Sciences must be reserved for a founder more worthy of its great objects— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came this afternoon and budded for memore cherry trees; with ox hearts and honey-hearts. He brought me three seedling Tupelo’s, sprung up under the tree, and which are precisely like my small Stranger in the middle garden-box— I bathed and swam about ten minutes at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf just before noon— Mary with her two children, and with Charles’s Louisa, went and took tea at Mrs. T. B. Adams’s— There was a distant thunder-shower in the Evening, of which a small portion extended to us, and which obliged them to send for Gillet with his Cariole, to bring them home.

26. IV. Sunday:— Heard Mr Lunt in the morning from 1 Peter 3.15. “But sanctify the Lord God in your hearts: and be ready always to give an answer to every man that asketh you a reason of the hope that is in you, with meekness and fear.” The Sermon was an argument to shew that religion was natural to the human mind— That it was one of the necessities of man’s nature, and so no doubt it is— The dilemma to which the human mind is reduced appears to be this— Matter exists from all eternity, or there is a first cause existing from eternity—now it is more difficult to conceive of the eternal existence of matter, than of a predisposing creating cause—intelligent of cause and effect— When we ask ourselves whence and how this material creation came into existence, the very conception which enables us to ask the question is an attribute not pertaining to matter. Why do we ask ourselves the question? why are we capable of conceiving the ideas of a Creator of eternity, of our own existence before our birth, and after our death— Why is it that upon the Planet which we inhabit, there is but one animal, of the innumerable multitudes which swarm upon it endowed with the faculty of reason? That this Planet has not existed many thousand years, or at least that the animal Man has not been more than fifty or sixty centuries a dweller upon it is certain— The conception and desire of future existence, are the foundation of religion; and we say, the Creator is benevolent— He gives existence for enjoyment— If he has bounded our existence by the present life, why has he made us conceive of, and wish for another? The brute creation have no such conception—no such desire— They enjoy their existence while it lasts, without hope or fear of futurity— Man then is a religious animal—but what is the inference from this; and what is the true religion?— This must be the subject of another Discourse— Mr. Lunt’s afternoon Sermon was from Matthew 13.31. [“]Another parable put he forth unto them, saying the kingdom of Heaven, is like to a grain of mustard-seed, which a man took and sowed in his field: 32. Which indeed is the least of all seeds: but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs, and becometh a tree, so that the birds of the air come, and lodge in the branches thereof.” This was upon the universality of the Christian Religion— Mr Lunt gave notice that the Communion would be administered next Sunday— Mary and the three children went to meeting this morning; and I took Mary-Louisa with me this afternoon— I read the 3d. Sermon of the 7th Volume of Saurin, upon the compassions of God— This is one of the most remarkable Discourses of the whole collection, and which would deserve to be studied with close Meditation— The doctrine that divine Mercy, must be always understood as an attribute harmonizing, with other attributes, and that the perfection of omnipotence consists in this harmony, leads to many important reflections— There is a mere glancing at the Trinity as if the
Preacher felt that it belonged to his subject, but dared not approach it— I read a few pages of Milman’s History of the Jews, and completed the copy into my last volume of Diary, of the rubbish notes I had taken from 10. January to 31. March 1833— This was the anniversary of my wedding day, and I made my Grand-daughter Mary-Louisa begin with it the reading of the Bible.
27. IV. Monday— Sun rose 4:45. clear.

Wilson took the sick horse to a farmer at Roxbury, by the name of Brown, who promises to return him sound in one month. Visiting my garden, nursery and seminary I find daily, some new thing to observe, but seldom any thing from which I derive any useful knowledge— It is but now that I am duly impressed with the indispensable necessity of shading the seedlings of the present year, though I have lost, within the last seven years at least a thousand trees by neglecting that caution— I have hitherto paid little attention to the old fruit trees—some of which bear almost every year with great profusion— I have now had them trimmed and their dead limbs taken off— The progress of the young fruit trees in the garden is excessively slow, and that of the young forest trees as rapid— There is a young Pear tree, from a sucker of an old stump bark bound in which for the last five or six years I have every year opened a slit in the bark— It shews a green and thrifty top, but is still bark-bound, and bears no fruit— I had it this day washed, and the Earth loosened round its roots— The Philadelphia Maple at the corner of the Seminary opens its seventh pair of leaves, and is nine inches high— The growth of all the rest is comparatively slow— I sowed Cheat and Melon-Seeds at the North east corner of the Seminary, and staked a twig of willow next the new pignut in the Honey-locust patch— After dinner I sent to Gillet for a Carriole, and horse, and Wilson drove me to Hingham— I took my three Grand-children with me, and Mrs Wilson, to nurse Charles’s Louisa; who was nevertheless, one moment sick, in the homeward ride— I went first to the house, and then to the Office of Mr Solomon Lincoln, to whom I gave the Papers of Mr Charles Lane, which have been returned to me by Henry L. Ellsworth Superintendent of the Patent Office, for a model; without which Mr Ellsworth in his Letter says that a Patent cannot be issued— I had an hour’s conversation with Mr Lincoln—upon the second centennial anniversary of the Settlement of Hingham, which they are about to commemorate—upon the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, upon which there is a partial agitation, in this part of the Country at this time; a border-eddy running counter to the general current of the tide; and upon some other topics, casually introduced— We returned and reached home just before Sunset— I began the redemption of arrears from the 26th. of December last, in my Journal, but found such deficiency of sybil-leaved minutes, that I postponed that for further materials, and began upon the arrear from 5. March 1834— It took so much time to collect the scattered rubbish sheets that my progress was very small— I received a Letter from Samuel Burch, with the Journal of the House of Representatives, for the first and second Session of the 22d. Congress— I had on Saturday received the Journal of the first Session of the 23d Congress— That of the second Session of the 23d. Congress—that is, the last Session and which contains the Oration on the Life and character of La Fayette, Mr Burch promises to send me in a few days.
28. IV. Tuesday. Sun rose 4:46—in Haze.

I water every morning the seedling trees which have come up this year in my flower pots, but with some doubts whether it is of any benefit to them. I leave those in the garden, Nursery and Seminary wholly unwatered the scorching Sun of the last four days, became this day covered with clouds, and the weather cool—but drought succeeds to heat, and the growth of my seedlings is suspended— I heard my two grand-children read— My Son Charles came out from Boston to pass the night here the 6th. number of his Appeal from the new to the old whigs was this day published in the Daily Boston Advocate— My progress in redeeming the arrears of my last volume of Journal, in March 1834. is slower than it was upon those of 1833: and I can give only an indifferent account of this day— I received a Letter from Mr Robert Charles Winthrop, reminding me of the adjourned meeting of the Alumni of Harvard College, on the first Monday of next Month, at Boston—and notifying me that it will be next Monday, at ten O’Clock A.M. At the Hall of the Academy of Arts and Sciences in State Street.
29. IV. Wednesday.

Copious showers all the morning, at first with Thunder and Lightening— They confined me to the House. My Son Charles, after dinner returned to Boston with his daughter Louisa-Catherine, who has been a fortnight here— A man by the name of Dominick Moglia, a Savoyard of Chambery, came as a mendicant, with certificates and recommendations engrossed upon parchment and also printed— He was coming to settle in this Country, but by Shipwreck was cast upon the island of Martinique— Thence by the charity of a benevolent Captain of a merchant vessel he obtained a free passage to this country, and now roams about for contributions to enable him to go back to Chambery and bring his family here— There is a class of beggars of this description constantly wandering about the Country; all having nearly the same story to tell; and all armed with certificates and recommendations from Clergymen, and Magistrates and Consuls and other official personages, who pay their own tribute thus, by taxing others for money— My tenant of the mount Wollaston farm came this evening to speak about the renewal of his lease which expires on the next 31st. of March— I told him I should ask 800 dollars a year for the rent of the place, and for that would give him a lease for five years defeasible by either party with one year’s notice— He said he could not afford to give that rent. I replied that he might take his own time for consideration, and then make me an offer— He objected to this, for fear that somebody should offer more than he could give; but I told him, I had made him a specific offer—if it did not suit him, he must either say what would, or quit the place— Well he said that was fair enough, and began to talk of repairs, and improvements, and putting the farm in order— I said he must let me know what he wanted in this respect, and what it would cost. He asked me to go down upon the farm, and said he would shew me, what he should wish to have done. I promised to go next Saturday afternoon, if the weather should be fair and cool— I heard my Granddaughters read twice, and laboured upon the arrears of my Diary— Paid a short visit to my Garden and Nursery; and read Edward Everett’s 4th. of July Oration, delivered at Beverly, which he has sent me
30. IV:10 Thursday— Foggy morning— Afternoon Shower— Evening clear

I wrote a short Letter to George Sullivan, declining to deliver the anniversary Address to the American Institute of the City of New-York next October— The multiplication of these Addresses, Orations and Discourses, of late years has made them all somewhat cheap— They give a peculiar character to the Literature of the Country— I am sometimes doubtful, whether I might not have rendered some service to the community by accepting occasionally some of those invitations; and particularly whether I might not have employed my time more usefully this Summer, by delivering three or four of the score of Orations and Addresses, for which I have been solicited, than by wasting it as I am, in mere copying from loose sheets into a bound book my own dull diary— So it is that I am never satisfied with myself— I had this day no interruption of visitors, but heard my Grandchildren read twice— Spent three of the best hours of the day, in my Garden, Nursery and Seminary, and performed rather more than my average daily task of copying, because I was able to write after dinner— I had sowed some of the earliest strawberries ripe, on the 22d of June—yesterday I gathered a few of the latest, and of these, sowed eleven this day in the Summer house Cellar, across from the willow tree, to the row of pignuts— The young Pear tree about the centre of the Garden bears well this year—and this day some of its fruit was first ripe— I see the first leaves of currant bushes, along under the fence at the North end of my Nursery. Nothing else will grow there, under the shade of the English Oaks and Elms.

31. IV.15. Saturday. Another day without interruption of visitors— Afternoon Thunder-shower, followed by heavy rain in the Evening— I heard my Grand daughters read twice, and proceeded with the arrears of my Diary in March 1834. Enclosed sundry Pamphlet copies of the performances at the Installation of the Revd. William Parsons Lunt, as Colleague Pastor with the Revd Peter Whitney, and wrote a short Letter to Samuel Burch— The 7th. number of the appeal from the new to the Old whigs was this day published in the Boston Daily Advocate— These papers contain a critical review of Daniel Webster’s last Winters Speech upon J. C. Calhoun’s Patronage Bill— Since the existence of the Government of the United States, there has not been so dangerous an assault upon the Constitution, as that Bill, which actually passed the Senate, at the last Session of Congress— Webster’s Speech in its favour carried it through— That Speech has been thoroughly exposed, and the principles of the Constitution have been indicated in these papers written entirely by my Son Charles— They have been published simultaneously in the Advocate, and in the Centinel, but have hitherto been unnoticed by any attempt of Webster or his friends to answer them— They are republished, in the Anti-masonic Newspapers at Bridgewater in Plymouth County and at Concord in Middlesex; but on the part of the new whigs have as yet been received in profound silence— My wife was ill in the Night.

Day. The same as the last Month— That is an entire waste of Time— The only useful part of my occupations is that of hearing my grand-children read— My mind is in a cocoon— My visits to my garden, nursery and seminary are as unprofitable as pilgrimages to the shrine of Saints— My copying, is Time thrown away— At this close of the Month I count in my Eastern close Seminary, alive 121 seedling Oaks, 30. Apple trees, 16 Pears, 9. Maples of the seed from Philadelphia 7. Peach-trees, 2 Pignut Hickories 4. Grape-vines, and 1. wild cherry— About half of them have been so scorched by the Sun, that their vegetation has been arrested and they will probably die— There are many seedlings scattered over the garden, and about 40 Oaks in the Nursery.
